revisions.rev:
{{Infobox college lacrosse team |name = Florida Gators women's lacrosse |founded = 2010 |image = Florida Gators logo.svg |image_size = 175 |university = [[University of Florida]] |conference = [[American Lacrosse Conference]] |division = |location = [[Gainesville, Florida]] |coach = [[Amanda O'Leary]] |tenure = since 2010 |stadium = Donald R. Dizney Stadium |capacity = 1,500 |nickname = [[Florida Gators]] |colors = Orange and Blue
{{colorbox|#FF4A00}} {{colorbox|#0021A5}} |NCAA_champion = |NCAA_runner = |NCAA_semi = |NCAA_quarter = 2011 |NCAA_tourney = 2011 |conf_tourney = |conf_champion = 2011 }} The '''Florida Gators women's lacrosse''' team represents the [[University of Florida]] in the sport of college [[field lacrosse|lacrosse]]. The Gators compete in [[Division I (NCAA)|Division I]] of the [[National Collegiate Athletics Association]] (NCAA) and the [[American Lacrosse Conference]] (ALC). They play their home games in Donald R. Dizney Stadium on the university's [[Gainesville, Florida]] campus, and are currently led by head coach [[Amanda O'Leary]]. In the two-season history of the Gators women's lacrosse program, the team has won one ALC championship and advanced to the quarterfinals of the 2011 NCAA national championship tournament. == Background and overview == The [[University of Florida Athletic Association|University Athletic Association]] (UAA) quickly proceeded from new idea to reality in the creation of its newest sports program—it decided to create a women's [[lacrosse]] program in 2005, publicly announced the new program in 2006, hired a head coach and joined a conference in 2007, and announced its first recruiting class and began construction of a dedicated lacrosse stadium in 2008.''[http://www.gatorzone.com/lacrosse/media/2011/supplement.pdf Florida Lacrosse 2011 Media Supplement]'', University Athletic Association, Gainesville, Florida, pp. 8–9, 43, 49 (2011). Retrieved May 4, 2011. UAA officials selected women's lacrosse for its newest expansion sport because of the booming popularity of lacrosse at the high school level and the rapidly increasing competition available among Division I athletic programs.Adam West, "[http://www.gainesville.com/article/20100219/articles/100219316?p=1&tc=pg Years in the making, Florida lacrosse debuts Saturday]," ''The Gainesville Sun'' (February 19, 2010). Retrieved May 4, 2011. Although the University of Florida is a long-time member of the [[Southeastern Conference]] (SEC) for the other twenty NCAA sports in which it fields varsity teams,''See, generally'', [http://www.secsports.com/index.php SECSports.com]. Retrieved May 4, 2011. the Florida Gators women's lacrosse team competes in the American Lacrosse Conference (ALC).''See'' [http://www.americanlacrosseconference.org/ American Lacrosse Conference website]. Retrieved May 4, 2011. Among the other eleven SEC member schools, only [[Vanderbilt University]] currently sponsors a varsity women's lacrosse team.VUCommodores.com, [http://vucommodores.cstv.com/sports/w-lacros/ Lacrosse Team]. Retrieved May 4, 2011. The inaugural Florida Gators team played teams from fellow ALC member schools [[Johns Hopkins Blue Jays women's lacrosse|Johns Hopkins]], Ohio State, Penn State, Vanderbilt and defending NCAA champion [[Northwestern Wildcats women's lacrosse|Northwestern]], as well as non-conference opponents Cornell, [[Georgetown Hoyas women's lacrosse|Georgetown]], Navy and New Hampshire during the spring 2010 semester. The Gators played their first regular season game on February 20, 2010, posting a 16–6 victory over the Jacksonville Dolphins."[http://laxmagazine.com/college_women/DI/2009-10/news/022010_gators_pounce_on_jacksonville_in_rousing_debut Gators Pounce on Dolphins in Rousing Debut]," ''Lacrosse Magazine'' (February 20, 2010). Retrieved May 4, 2011. It was the second Division I lacrosse game played by a Florida-based team in the state of Florida, and the first between two in-state programs. The Dolphins played the first Division I women's game in the state on February 6, 2010. ''See'' Jacksonville Dolphins, [http://www.judolphins.com/wlacrosse/ Lacrosse]. Retrieved May 4, 2011. The young Gators finished their inaugural season 10–8, including ALC wins over Penn State and John Hopkins, and were ranked eighteenth in the country in LaxPower's final power ratings.LaxPower.com, Women's College Lacrosse 2010, [http://www.laxpower.com/update10/binwom/rating01.php Women's Division I Computer Ratings]. Retrieved May 4, 2011. In only their second season of NCAA competition, the sixth-ranked Gators clinched their first ALC regular season championship by defeating the defending conference champion and second-ranked [[Northwestern Wildcats]] 13–11 on April 14, 2011.Jeff Barlis, "[http://www.gatorsports.com/article/20110414/ARTICLES/110419680/1136?Title=Lacrosse-tops-No-2-Northwestern Lacrosse tops No. 2 Northwestern]," ''The Gainesville Sun'' (April 14, 2011). Retrieved May 4, 2011. The Gators completed a perfect 5–0 ALC season three days later when they defeated the seventeenth-ranked [[Vanderbilt Commodores]] 8–7."[http://www.gatorsports.com/article/20110418/ARTICLES/110419501/1136?Title=UF-lacrosse-team-makes-history UF lacrosse team makes history]," ''The Gainesville Sun'' (April 18, 2011). Retrieved May 4, 2011. The Northwestern Wildcats edged the Gators 10–9 in the ALC Tournament final, after the Gators defeated the Ohio State Buckeyes 16–13 in the semifinal round. The Gators received their first NCAA Tournament bid, seeded fourth in the sixteen-team field on May 9, 2011,"[http://www.gatorsports.com/article/20110508/ARTICLES/110509523/1136?Title=UF-lacrosse-a-No-4-seed-in-NCAAs UF lacrosse a No. 4 seed in NCAAs]," ''The Gainesville Sun'' (May 8, 2011). Retrieved May 10, 2011. and defeated the Stanford Cardinal women's team 13–11 in the first round of the NCAA tournament five days later.Kevin Brockway, "[http://www.gatorsports.com/article/20110514/ARTICLES/110519706/1136?Title=UF-advances-in-NCAA-lacrosse-after-beating-Stanford UF advances in NCAA after beating Stanford]," ''The Gainesville Sun'' (May 14, 2011). Retrieved May 15, 2011. The young Gators eventually fell to the veteran [[Duke Blue Devils]] 13—9 in the quarterfinals ("Elite Eight") of the 2011 NCAA Tournament, finishing their second season with an overall win-loss record of 16–4.Jeff Barlis, "[http://www.gatorsports.com/article/20110521/ARTICLES/110529932/1136?Title=UF-lacrosse-season-ends-with-NCAA-loss-vs-Duke UF lacrosse season ends with NCAA loss vs. Duke]," ''The Gainesville Sun'' (May 21, 2011). Retrieved May 21, 2011. In advance of the spring 2012 season, ''[[Lacrosse Magazine]]'' ranked the Gators as the preseason No. 2 team in the nation."[http://web.gatorzone.com/story.php?id=21246 Lacrosse Magazine Tabs Florida Gators Preseason No. 2]," GatorZone.com (September 7, 2011). Retrieved September 7, 2011. == Coaching staff == Florida named [[Amanda O'Leary]] as its inaugural head coach on June 22, 2007.GatorZone.com, Lacrosse, Coaching & Support Staff, [http://gatorzone.com/lacrosse/staff/oleary Amanda O'Leary]. Retrieved May 4, 2011. Before she became Florida's first head coach, O'Leary served as the head coach at [[Yale University]] for fourteen seasons, and was previously an assistant coach at the [[University of Maryland, College Park|University of Maryland]] and the [[University of Delaware]]. As a collegiate player, O'Leary was honored as a two-time All-American [[Field lacrosse#Midfielders|midfielder]] at [[Temple University]], where she led her [[Temple Owls]] team to an NCAA Championship in 1988. Assistant coach Erica LaGrow is a second-year Gators assistant.GatorZone.com, Lacrosse, Coaching & Support Staff, [http://www.gatorzone.com/lacrosse/staff/lagrow Erica LaGrow]. Retrieved May 4, 2011. She was a first-team All-[[Atlantic Coast Conference]] (ACC) midfielder for the [[North Carolina Tar Heels]], and graduated from the University of North Carolina in 2008. LaGrow currently plays for the U.S. Women's Elite Lacrosse team, and was a key player on the U.S. national team that defeated Australia in the gold medal game of the 2009 [[Federation of International Lacrosse]] (FIL) Women's World Cup. Assistant coach Caitlyn McFadden is a first-year Gators assistant.GatorZone.com, Lacrosse, Coaching & Support Staff, [http://www.gatorzone.com/lacrosse/staff/mcfadden Caitlyn McFadden]. Retrieved May 4, 2011. She played for the [[Maryland Terrapins]], and graduated from the University of Maryland in 2010 after leading the Terps to the 2010 NCAA Championship. McFadden was an IWLCA first-team All-American midfielder in her junior and senior seasons. As a senior, she was the recipient of the [[Tewaarton Award]] and [[Honda Sports Award]], and was named the ACC Player of the Year, the NCAA Tournament Most Valuable Player, and the IWLCA National Midfielder of the Year. The Maryland Terrapins sports program honored her with its Suzanne Tyler Award, given to the University of Maryland female athlete of the year. == Building the future == The first Gators recruiting class of twenty-four players"Women's Lacrosse: University of Florida announces first lacrosse class," ''Inside Lacrosse'' (November 20, 2008). Retrieved January 29, 2010."[http://www.gatorzone.com/story.php?id=14874 First Gator Lacrosse Signing Class Announced]" GatorZone.com (November 19, 2008). Retrieved May 4, 2011. included seven US Lacrosse first-team high school All-Americans—Caroline Chesterman, Katie Ciaci, Brittany Dashiell, Samantha Farrell, Janine Hiller, Jamie Reeg and Julie Schindel, and US Lacrosse named another five as All-American Honorable MentionsâAshley Bruns, Lelan Bailey, Jenna Hildebrand, Hayley Katzenberger and Mikey Meagher.LaxPower.com, [http://www.laxpower.com/all-amer/aa-list-hs.php?SelYear=2009&SelGender=G&SelList=AA US Lacrosse 2009 High School All-Americans]. Retrieved May 4, 2011. Dashiell, Bruns and Farrell, plus Kitty Cullen, Colby Rhea and Haydon Judge, were also named Under Armour All-Americans.Dave Yanovtiz, "[http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/06/25/AR2009062503892.html Florida Loads Up on Locals: Gatore' Inaugural Roster Full of Area Players]," ''The Washington Post'' (June 26, 2009). Retrieved May 4, 2011. Aaron Wright, "Before heading to Florida, six local girls team up at 'Classic': Gators will rely heavily on six Under Armour All-Americans in first season," ''Baltimore Sun'' (June 27, 2009). Retrieved July 5, 2009. Amanda Wedekind was previously named an Under Armour All-American as a rising sophomore in 2006. The Gators' 2009–2010 recruiting class was rated best in the nation.Patrick Carney, "[http://sports.espn.go.com/ncaa/news/story?id=4943749 Florida lacrosse starts strong]," ESPN.com (February 25, 2010). Retrieved March 1, 2010. == Donald R. Dizney Stadium == Completed during the summer of 2009, Donald R. Dizney Stadium hosts the Gators women's lacrosse team.Robbi Andreu, "[http://www.gainesville.com/article/20090308/ARTICLES/903080957?Title=Lacrosse-ready-to-get-dream-home Lacrosse ready to get 'dream' home]," ''The Gainesville Sun'' (March 8, 2009). Retrieved May 4, 2011. The facility includes a 1,500-seat stadium that runs the length of the game field. The $15 million construction cost was funded entirely by private donors. The facility also includes a second practice field, concessions stands, locker rooms, a training room, and other amenities.GatorZone.com, Lacrosse, Facilities, [http://gatorzone.com/facilities/?venue=lacrosse&sport=lacro Donald R. Dizney Stadium at Florida Lacrosse Facility]. Retrieved May 4, 2011. At the Gators' first home game, an overflow crowd of 2,214 was present in Dizney Stadium for the Gators' 16–6 win over the Jacksonville Dolphins. == See also == *[[Florida Gators]] *[[History of the University of Florida]] *[[List of University of Florida buildings]] *[[University of Florida Athletic Association|University Athletic Association]] *[[Women's lacrosse]] == References == {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} == External links == * [http://www.americanlacrosseconference.org/ American Lacrosse Conference] – Official website of the American Lacrosse Conference. * [http://www.gatorsports.com/section/gatorslacrosse GatorSports.com] – Florida Gators women's lacrosse news from ''The Gainesville Sun''. * [http://web.gatorzone.com/lacrosse/ GatorZone.com] – Official webpage of the Florida Gators women's lacrosse team. {{Florida Gators athletic program navbox}} {{Florida Gators women's lacrosse}} [[Category:College lacrosse teams in the United States]] [[Category:Florida Gators|Lacrosse]] [[Category:Lacrosse teams in Florida]] [[Category:Sports clubs established in 2010]] [[Category:Women's lacrosse]]
